text: we have an opportunity to talk to one of
the world's leading stem cell
researchers she has pioneered new
understandings of skin diseases and care
in a variety of others because of her
pioneering work we've invited her here
to talk to you about not only science
but her personal journey her personal
career and certainly what it's like to
be a woman in the world of sciences it
is so important for students to realize
that we scientists are passionate about
the science that we do but we started
out as they did there are several things
that keep me doing what I'm doing and
the first and foremost is passion I
think we all have passion about what it
is that we choose to do in life and it
took me a while to find my passion but
once I found it then I knew I was in the
right field I knew what I wanted to do
and there was going to be nothing
stopping me
we are still many many years later
passionate about the science that we do
and I think conveying that to high
school students is one of the best ways
that we can to to really propagate the
interest that they have in science and
and research and in choosing a career
for science the interest that I have
that interest really developed starting
out much as you probably have done and
that is that you notice life outside of
you outside of your household you or
your noticing animals you notice plants
you begin to wonder about where all of
this comes from and how it comes about
and and so it really started for me with
a butterfly net in in the fields outside
of Chicago this experience was
definitely once we remembered it
definitely inspired me to pursue my
career in science and I encouraged
others if they're able to attend this
seminar because she definitely is an
inspiration to the science world and I
think whether you're in Afghanistan
whether you're in Central Park in New
York City that there are ways in which
you can study science get interested in
science and once you've got that passion
for for what it is that you want to do I
just don't let anything get in your way
just keep moving keep trying I think the
world science festival has really been
inspirational for high school students
interested in science in New York City I
think it has reached out to really
worldwide to high school students from
many different countries we as
scientists are in the laboratory day in
day out and we're encountering barriers
all the time
the flashiness is that you make a
discovery and that discovery is
extremely extremely gratifying you're
discovering something that nobody else
has ever discovered but the way along
the road to discovery is a long road and
you're going to come up with excitement
but you're also going to come up with
failures and we're all facing barriers
in our life some smaller than others
some large but I think those barriers
are very are a very important part of
developing the drive the motivation to
succeed I think just go in there any if
in any case I end up facing in a
discrimination I'll definitely remember
and believe that anything is possible
into
there so the question then is is how
does my gender affect my my support for
embryonic stem cell research I feel that
ultimately it's a decision that that
really for me is really a gender blind
decision this study can really lead to
new and improved therapies and and
diagnostics and understanding of
different types of human diseases this
is amazing experience
I'm already pursuing my career as a
nurse future and this has helped me
understand what science is really about
instead of staying in school like just
learning from textbooks and you know
there's more out there than it's in
school was an amazing experience and I
would like to these more often it's
really a medically driven support for
this kind of research my own feeling
working on adult stem cells and
something that I probably will always
work on is that if I look at where
embryonic stem cell research has
developed over the last five years or so
those researchers working on embryonic
stem cells began to say well could we
actually create embryonic like stem
cells working starting with adult skin
the only way researchers would be able
to do that is by looking at the advances
that have been made many scientists are
not supportive of a study of human
embryos but I think many scientists are
supportive of the research that will
ultimately take them to new and improved
cures for human disease and I really
think this was I feel really blessed for
coming here and I think it's really just
like another step to go into genetics
when I go to college you talked a little
bit about government mission and clearly
for you the pinnacle must be with
President Obama presented you with this
science award tell us a little bit about
what it was like to be with President
Obama well it's really anytime you have
the opportunity in your lifetime to
shake hands with the president I
strongly recommend you don't turn that
opportunity it is it's obviously
thrilling us obviously it was a real
honor and a treat for me one of the
things that I think was very exciting
was that the ceremony took place in the
room where Thomas Jefferson was shown
the map of the West by Lewis and Clark
and so there was history and science
that really set the framework for the
setting and perhaps even more than
shaking the president pan was to listen
to the President of the United States
stand up and give a ten minute talk
about the importance of science the
importance of science at the educational
level where all of you are in science
classes the support that's necessary for
for providing you with the microscopes
and computers and various different
experimental needs to be able to really
learn and get excited about science my
name is David mica I'm the ap biology
teacher at Marble Hill School for
International Studies and I'm so happy
to bring 12 of my best students here
today to see that science is just not
something from a textbook science isn't
just something we read in journal
articles but it's something that we come
and get to interact with the researchers
here what they're doing see what they're
doing and maybe be inspired to go to
find our own career path in the future
as we were just talking Parker about the
importance of really being able to
provide government support for that
basic science that really leads to
biomedical research the importance of us
is the country continuing to be leaders
in biomedical research across the world
to continue in a way that that really is
funneling our our efforts our
intelligence our abilities into really
trying to help people and improve the
situation around the world and I think
science can be a great ambassador we
don't have a political agenda we just
have a passion and a conviction that of
what it is to be a scientist
I really enjoyed conversing with the
high school students they're persistent
they're excited about science and
whatever motivation I can provide to
fuel that fire that they have for
pursuing a career in science I think is
is really wonderful and it's wonderful
that the world science festival really

to New York City to to participate
